1.1  Introduction

Calpine Corporation operates the Los Medanos Energy Center, a nominal 500-megawatt power plant located in Pittsburg, California.  The Los Medanos Energy Center uses aqueous ammonia (24.5 percent solution) as a necessary part of reducing the emissions of nitrogen oxides to the atmosphere.  Storing a large quantity of ammonia can be a hazard if it is not handled properly.  As the company responsible for operating Los Medanos Energy Center, Calpine Corporation takes its safety obligations in storing and using ammonia as seriously as we take controlling emissions from the power plant.  The following document describes what could happen if there were to be an accident, the steps we take every day to ensure a safely operating plant, and what to do in the event of an emergency.

1.2  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The Los Medanos Energy Center accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach that integrates proven technology, staff training on operation and maintenance practices, and tested management system practices.  All applicable procedures of the State of California and U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Prevention Program are adhered to, including key elements such as training, systems management, and emergency response procedures.  

Calpine Corporation recognizes the responsibility to make our environment, community and employee safety a primary part of our daily concerns.  Calpine Corporation is committed to being a responsible member of any community in which it has operations by giving top priority to operating in a safe and environmentally sound manner.  Calpine is dedicated to developing an environmentally responsible energy resource compatible with community needs. 

Calpine aims to protect and conserve California's valuable air and water resources, while providing a reliable source of low-cost electricity for residents and businesses. Calpine is committed to working closely with comm

unity members, environmental groups and local governmental agencies to meet its obligation to the community and to the environment.

It is the policy of Calpine Corporation that every employee is entitled to a safe and healthful place in which to work and live. Calpine Operations and Maintenance Department incorporates the concepts of environmental responsibility and productivity with safety resulting in efficiency and productivity.  As part of Calpine?s obligation to protect the integrity of human, environmental, physical, and financial resources, and to conserve and efficiently utilize those resources, Calpine will:

Comply fully with laws regulating environmental protection and employee health and safety

Furnish work places free of recognized hazards likely to cause injury to employees, the public, or the environment

Train employees in safe and environmentally conscious practices and require compliance with environmental, health and safety regulations, policies, and procedures

Provide a professional staff to maintain and support environmental, health and safety programs

This document complies with the EPA Risk Management Program under Section 112 (r) of the Clean Air Act (CAA) Amendments of 1990, 40 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Part 68, and the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program under California Code of Regulations (CCR) Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5.  This document summarizes our existing health and safety programs, our internal management response procedures, and ongoing actions that are designed to prevent or minimize impacts of accidental releases of ammonia to the environment.  Los Medanos Energy Center has prepared an emergency action plan to handle any potential accidental releases.

1.3  Facility Description and Regulated Substances Information

The Los Medanos Energy Center is located approximately 0.5 miles northeast of Pittsburg, California in Contra Costa County.  LMEC is situated on a 12-acre site at East 3rd Stree

t, west of the intersection of East 3rd and Columbia.  The facility sits on the northwest corner of property owned by USS-POSCO Industries. The plant is a merchant facility marketing the electrical power on the open power exchange market and ancillary service support to the California Independent Systems Operator (CAL-ISO) grid. Electricity generated by this facility is transported by lines owned by Pacific Gas and Electric.  LMEC will provide steam and electricity to USS-POSCO and backup power to Dow Chemical. 

The facility currently stores aqueous ammonia, a regulated toxic substance under RMP and CalARP regulations, in two 10,000 gallon steel bulk storage tanks.  Ammonia is used at the Los Medanos Energy Center to reduce nitrogen oxides (NOx) created during the combustion of natural gas and exhausted from the two Combustion Turbine Generators (CTG) and Heat Recovery Steam Generators (HRSG) duct burners.  Ammonia is pumped from a storage tank, diluted with exhaust gases, and injected into the two Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) units to reduce the NOx emissions.

The maximum quantity of ammonia stored at Los Medanos Energy Center exceeds the federal RMP and CalARP specified threshold quantities of 20,000 pounds and 500 pounds, respectively; thus, the facility is subject to federal RMP and CalARP regulations.  The aqueous ammonia process is a Program 2 process.

1.4  Summary of the Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps 

Management System

Risk Management Program regulations require those facilities with processes subject to Program 2 to develop a management system to oversee the implementation of the RMP elements.  The management system must be assigned to a qualified person or position that will have the overall responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of the RMP.  

The Los Medanos Energy Center has assigned the Operations Manager as the qualified person who will have the overall responsibili

ty for the development, implementation, and integration of the RMP.  The Operations Manager will be assisted by the Health and Safety Manager and the Maintenance Manager in the implementation of the RMP.  Table 1-1 provides the details of the responsibilities of the key personnel in the implementation of the RMP.

The management system activities are further discussed below:

Planning ? Los Medanos Energy Center has an environmental, health, and safety policy that clearly define Calpine?s goals and obligations.

Organizing ? The Operations Manager is responsible for ensuring that written prevention  prevention procedures are in place and implements as described in the prevention program document.

Implementing ? The Operations Manager is responsible for implementing the Risk Management Program at Los Medanos Energy Center.  The Health and Safety Manager is responsible for arranging for  and tracking training for staff.

Controlling ? The Health and Safety Manager is responsible for conducting the internal compliance audits of the prevention program to ensure the procedures are being implemented by staff.  Unless otherwise indicated, RMP records are maintained for five years. 

Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

The prevention program elements described in the following section represent integrated administrative controls intended to ensure the safety of workers, the public, and the environment.  The program elements such as hazard reviews, compliance audits, and incident investigation result in the development of additional safeguards.  Some of the physical safeguards that are part of the original design and are already in place include the following:

Pressure Relief Valves.  Each aqueous ammonia storage tank is furnished with a pressure/vacuum relief valve assembly.  The valve is set to protect the tank form overpressurization and to limit vacuum in the tank to 2 ounces per square inch vacuum.  A pressure reducing station with appropriate pressure regulator, pres

sure gauge, valves, piping, and fittings are provided.  An external pressure relief valve returned back to the storage tank is supplied.

Shutoff Valves.  All piping connections, except those with safety relief devices or gauges, contain shutoff valves located as close as possible to the storage tank. 

Tank Level Indication. High and low tank level switches are provided on the storage tanks.  The high level switches are interlocked with the unloading pump.  The low level switches are interlocked with the supply pumps.  The level switches are wired to the local panel as well as the control room.  The interlocks included do not allow the unloading pump to operate with a high tank level in either tank.

Secondary Containment. The ammonia storage tanks are located in containment area that is 37 feet 6 inches long by 37 feet 4 inches wide by 2 feet 10 inches high.  This area is sufficient to contain the full contents of the ammonia storage tank.

Leak Detection.  Pressure gauges are located on the inner and outer shell of each ammonia tank to notify operators if there is a leak.  The pressure gauge have local indication and indication in the control room.

Underground Containment Tank.  The ammonia unloading area has been designed so that any spillage of aqueous ammonia would be directed to a sump where it will be valved and piped to an underground containment tank.   Except during delivery of ammonia, the valve to the containment tank will be kept closed.  Rainwater collected on the unloading station will be pumped out as needed.  The underground containment tank is equipped with a sump into which a submersible pump can be lowered to pump out the contents when required for disposal.

Emergency Shower and Eyewash. An emergency shower and eyewash station is located at the truck unloading station, within a few steps of the truck fill and vapor return connections.

Stop Valve. Two emergency stop valves are provided on the main liquid line on the tank suction.  The valve po

sition indication is wired directly to the DCS system.  In the event of a fire or ammonia spill, the operator is to manually initiate a valve closure.

Prevention Program Elements

The Los Medanos Energy Center accidental release prevention program is based on the following key elements:

Detailed management system and clear levels of responsibilities and team member roles

Comprehensive safety process information that is readily available to staff, emergency responders, and contractors

Comprehensive preventive maintenance program

A hazard review of equipment and procedures with operation and maintenance staff participation

Use of state-of-the-art process and safety equipment

Use of accurate and effective operating procedures, written with operations and maintenance staff participation

High level of training of operators and maintenance staff

Implementation of an incident investigation, inspection, and auditing program using qualified staff

Safety Information

Complete and up-to-date safety information is required to successfully implement most RMP elements including hazard reviews, training, emergency planning and response, management of change, incident investigation, and compliance audits.  RMP regulations require that information concerning process chemicals, process technology, and process equipment be compiled as part of a Prevention Program, prior to conducting a hazard review.  This information is used to identify and understand the hazards in operating the ammonia process. The Operations Manager is responsible for compiling and maintaining the following up-to-date safety information related to the regulated substances, processes, and equipment.

Comprehensive chemical data have been assembled to include regulatory reporting and action thresholds, health hazards, and chemical exposure limitations, as well as detailed physical properties of aqueous ammonia.  This information was compiled from numerous sources and is intended to be a one-stop source for

the reader seeking data about these substances.  This information includes ammonia background information, material safety data sheets (MSDS), and ammonia reaction chemistry.

Equipment safety information has been compiled on the ammonia process, and specifications for the process are compiled in one place for easy reference.  Details such as maximum intended inventory, safe upper and lower operating temperatures and pressures, and codes and standards used to design, build, and operate the processes are on file at the facility.  Calpine Corporation verify that that equipment complies with recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices by specifying that the latest codes and standards be used for the design of the plant, conducting a seismic assessment to confirm that process meets structural codes, and by reviewing the ammonia process in the hazard review.

We also have scheduled reviews of our risk management program to update safety information if there is a major change that would make existing information inaccurate.

Hazard Review 

The intent of the hazard review is to provide information that will assist Los Medanos Energy Center staff in making decisions for improving safety and reducing the consequences of hazardous accidental releases.  A hazard review is a systematic effort to evaluate potential causes and consequences of accidental releases.  The hazard review focuses on equipment, instrumentation, utilities, human factors, and external events, including seismic events that might affect the process.  

Several methodologies can be used to perform a Hazard Review or a Process Hazard Analysis as described in Guidelines for Hazard Evaluation Procedures, Second Edition with Worked Examples, Center for Chemical Process Safety of the American Institute of Chemical Engineers, 1992. For less complex systems the What-if Analysis/Checklist method is commonly used. The What-If Analysis is a brainstorming approach in which the Hazard Review team ident

ifies potential accidental release scenarios and recommendations for risk reduction.   The Checklist method uses industry checklists or checklists developed by staff familiar with the process. 

With the concurrence of the Contra Costa County Health Services Department, the What-If Analysis/Checklist method was selected for evaluating potential accidental releases at Los Medanos Energy Center.   Calpine Corporation believes this approach provides the most detailed and applicable level of analysis, incorporating both general industry information and plant-specific knowledge.

The initial aqueous ammonia Hazard Review was performed at LMEC on November 2, 2000.  The Hazard Review team consisted of process operating and maintenance personnel, health and safety personnel and engineers. Hazard Review team used a piping and instrumentation diagram to systematically identify causes of potential aqueous ammonia releases.    

The Hazard Review team brainstormed recommendations to reduce the risk of accidental aqueous ammonia releases for each significant release scenario.  Significant release scenarios were defined as any accidental release that would probably occur during the lifetime of LMEC and could result in an onsite injury requiring medical treatment, or any offsite injury or death.


The Hazard Review will be updated again within a 5-year period or whenever there is major change in the process.  A list of actions to resolve any significant findings from the analysis was prepared and included confirming vendor procedures, posting speed limits, posting unloading procedures, confirming maintenance procedures, and labeling the tank fill lines.  Los Medanos Energy Center staff is currently working to resolve this action item list. No significant recommendations were made as a result of the seismic assessment except to perform a follow up inspection on the few remaining portions of the system that had not yet been installed.  Staff will document completion of each action i

tem .

Operating Procedures

Los Medanos Energy Center maintains up-to-date, accurate, written operating procedures that give clear instructions for the ammonia process. Effective operating procedures, when combined with operator training, are instrumental in ensuring safe operation of the systems and preventing accidental releases.  The procedures are developed from equipment manuals and the experience of the operations and maintenance staff. Procedures include startup, shutdown, and normal operations, abnormal (emergency) operations, emergency shutdown, and startup after emergency shutdown.   The operating procedures also include safe work practices for hazardous material handling.   The operating procedures are accessible to all staff and are maintained in the control room.

If operating procedures require changing because of a modification to the process, they must be updated and recertified in accordance with management of change (MOC) procedures.  Changes that may require updating of operating procedures include changes in process chemicals, changes in process technology, and equipment and facility changes.

If the operating procedures must be modified, the Operations Manager or designee will be responsible for modifying the procedure.  The Operations Manager will review the draft-revised procedures and sign the approval page.  The Operations Manager will forward the revised procedures to the General Manager for approval and signature. The Operations Manager must update all copies of the operating procedures. 
After completing this review, the Operations Manager will certify each operating procedure as accurate and reflective of current operating practice.  The date that the procedures were modified will be listed on the first page of each operating procedure.  A memorandum should be prepared summarizing who reviewed and modified the procedures, the dates the work was done, who reviewed the revisions, the rationale for the changes, and the date the revised pro

cedures were approved by the Operations Manager.
If any operations or maintenance staff member believes that the operating procedures should be modified to improve system safety and reliability, that person should notify their supervisor, who will determine if the procedures should be modified and, if modification is required, initiate the procedures previously described to modify the operating procedures.  

Staff designated by the Operations Manager will communicate revisions to the appropriate plant operations and maintenance staff.  If revisions are significant, a formal training session will be held to communicate the changes.  The communication to plant operations staff should be documented in a memorandum.  The Operations Manager will ensure that the operating procedures are updated if necessary whenever a major change occurs and prior to start up of the changed process.

Training Program

Each Los Medanos Energy Center employee presently involved in operating or maintaining the ammonia process is trained in an overview of the process and applicable operating and maintenance procedures.  Training helps employees understand the nature and cause of problems arising from operations involving ammonia, and increases employee awareness of hazards.  Los Medanos Energy Center?s training program includes both initial and refresher training that covers:  (1) a general overview of the processes, (2) the properties and hazards of the substances in the process, and (3) a detailed review of the process operating procedures and safe work practices.  Oral reviews and written self-evaluations are used to verify that an employee understands the training material before the process work can be resumed. 

Training documentation includes:  date of most recent review or revision to the training program, type of training required and the type of competency testing used to ensure staff understands the training.  Ongoing employee training records are maintained.  

Maintenance

Los M

edanos Energy Center maintains the mechanical integrity of process equipment to help prevent equipment failures that could endanger workers, the public, or the environment.  We believe that this program is the primary line of defense against a release.  Maintenance staff address equipment testing and inspection, preventative maintenance schedules, and personnel training of these procedures.  Our maintenance program includes the following:

Written procedures for maintaining mechanical integrity through inspection and testing of process equipment, based on instructions of equipment vendors, industry codes, and prior operating experience

Implementation of written procedures by performing inspections and tests on process equipment at specified intervals

Training of maintenance personnel in safe work practices such as lockout/tagout, line or equipment opening, and avoidance and correction of unsafe conditions

Procedures specifying training requirements for contract maintenance employees, as well as requiring contractors to use plant-developed maintenance procedures for process areas

Internal Compliance Audits

Internal compliance audits are conducted every three years to verify compliance with the programs and procedures contained in the RMP. The Health and Safety Manager will assemble a team that includes at least one person knowledgeable in the ammonia process and an audit leader knowledgeable in RMP requirements and audit techniques.  A person is considered knowledgeable if they have operated or maintained the ammonia process for more than one year or have prepared RMPs for ammonia systems. An outside consultant or an internal team may be used to perform the compliance audit.

The audit team evaluates whether the prevention program satisfies the requirements of the RMP rule and whether the prevention program is sufficient to help ensure safe operation.   A series of questions on a Compliance Audit Questionnaire will be answered by conducting equipment inspections

, record reviews and interviews.   

The audit team will summarize the results of the compliance audit in a Compliance Audit Report of Findings.  The report will record RMP program deficiencies identified by the team, the corrective actions to be taken, the staff assigned to implement the corrective actions, and the target completion date.  All identified corrective actions will be assigned by the Operations Manager to the appropriate staff for follow-up.  MOC procedures will be followed before corrective action is taken.  

It will be the responsibility of the Health and Safety Manager to ensure all audit corrective actions are resolved or implemented in a timely manner and the resolution thoroughly documented.  The documentation should include a summary of the corrective action taken, the staff member implementing the action, and the date completed.  Whenever a corrective action is not implemented, a written explanation will be prepared explaining why the action is no longer appropriate or no longer applicable.

Incident Investigation

Each incident that resulted in or could reasonably have resulted in a catastrophic release of aqueous ammonia  must be investigated.  The purpose of this section describes a process that can be used to identify the underlying causes of incidents and implement procedures to prevent similar events from occurring in the future.

The incident investigation procedure covers the RMP regulated process (aqueous ammonia) at Los Medanos Energy Center.  This procedure applies to all incidents that result in or could have resulted in a catastrophic releases.  A catastrophic release is defined as a major uncontrolled emission, fire, or explosion involving one or more regulated substances that presents imminent and substantial endangerment to public health and the environment or presents serious danger to employees at Los Medanos Energy Center.  Calpine?s policy is to go further and investigate all reportable releases as well.
The Operations Mana

ger shall establish an incident investigation team to investigate the incident.  

The investigation process is initiated with the report of the incident to the Operations Manager by the staff involved in the incident.  The Operations  Manager and Maintenance Manager should be notified of the incident immediately after it occurs.  When appropriate emergency response actions have stabilized the situation and conditions onsite are safe, the Operations Manager shall begin the investigation and serve as the leader of the investigation.  The investigation must begin within 48 hours after the incident occurred. The investigation team, as a group, will investigate the incident by:

Interviewing staff involved in the incident

Interviewing other staff who have knowledge about the process that may be helpful in the investigation

Checking records such as alarm printouts

Discussing the incident as a group

Physically examining the process

Calpine has complied a series of questions to help the investigation team identify some of the less obvious ways of preventing incidents.

The Incident Investigation Team prepares a report on the incident.  Recommendations resulting from the investigation report will then be assigned by the Operations Manager to the appropriate staff (operations maintenance, or engineering personnel) for prompt followup.  Recommendations often require additional evaluation to determine if they are technically and/or economically feasible; therefore, the Operations Manager shall also list the target evaluation date, resolution and resolution date for each recommendation.

Process Modifications 

Los Medanos Energy Center ensures that a pre-startup safety review is completed for any new regulated process at the plant, or for significant modifications to an existing covered process that requires a change in the process safety information.  Los Medanos Energy Center provides a system and approach to maintain and implement management of changes or modifications

to equipment, procedures, chemicals, and processing conditions.  This system allows our employees to identify and review safety hazards or provide additional safety, process, or chemical information before the proposed change is implemented.

1.5  Five-Year Accident History Summary

EPA RMP regulations require reporting the five-year accident history of the covered processes.  The details of accidental releases are required for accidents that have caused at least one of the following:

Onsite deaths, injuries, or significant property damage

Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place

Los Medanos Energy Center has had no accidents involving ammonia.

1.6  Emergency Response Program Summary

Los Medanos Energy Center has established a written emergency action program that is followed by the employees to help safely control accidental releases of hazardous substances. This program has been coordinated (reviewed) by the CCCHSD and the Contra Costa County Fire Protection Department, which are members of the Local Emergency Response Planning Committee (LEPC).  Emergency operation and action procedures are also reviewed once per year. 

1.78  Planned Changes to Improve Safety

During the process hazard analysis, several additional risk reduction measures were recommended to improve safety at Los Medanos Energy Center.  These measures included posting speed limits near the ammonia tanks, posting the unloading procedure near the tank, and confirming that the ammonia vendor has a preventive maintenance program for the delivery truck hoses.
